metadata.title: Thermal behavior of aqueous iron oxide nano‐fluid as a coolant on a flat disc heater under the pool boiling condition

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Boiling heat transfer is an efficient and cost-effective mechanism, which has wide application in cooling and power
* M. M. Sarafraz mohamadmohsensarafraz@gmail.com
1 Department of Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Mahshahr Branch, Islamic Azad University, Mahshahr, Iran
2 Faculty of Chemical, Petroleum and Gas Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan, Iran
1 3
cycles. In fact, a larger quantity of heat can be removed from the heating surface and can be transferred to the cold environment in comparison with other heat transfer mechanisms. As boiling has complexities due to the bubble formation e.g. bubble transport, nucleation, bubble frequency and bubble sliding. Moreover, during boiling phenomenon, a bubble can be formed, grow and collapse inside the bulk of fluid, which transfers a large quantity of heat from surface towards the bulk of fluid [1–3].
Critical heat flux, (CHF) in boiling heat transfer, as a definition, is the limited point in which, phase change process acts in a way that bubbles can fully cover and overwhelm the heating surface, which lead to the overheating problem. In this condition, heat transfer coefficient starts to be deteriorated over the higher given heat fluxes, as heat cannot be transferred from the surface towards the bulk of coolant, which can finally damage the surface or explode the heater. Therefore, to have an efficient cooling system, efforts should be made to increase the CHF point [4].
Nano-fluid is an engineered colloid comprising of solid particles 0–100 nm, which are dispersed into the conventional coolant e.g. water, ethylene glycol and are nominated as a promising way to enhance the thermal performance of cooling systems and a good option for CHF prevention purposes. Such nano-suspensions have higher thermal conductivity in comparison with conventional fluids, so they can be utilized for high heat flux applications and as efficient cooling working mediums [5]. Reference should be sorted.
Although the nano-fluids have considerably higher thermal conductivity rather than traditional coolants, fouling formation or deposition of particles on the heating surface is regarded as the major drawback of using this colloid as a coolant. Therefore, this has been an incentive for the researchers to conduct investigations on the potential cooling application of nano-fluids. For instance, Bahrami et al. [6] investigated the dynamics of bubbles in pool boiling of nano-fluid with coated and sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) solution with different nano-particles. In addition, the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) module was used for mathematical modeling of bubbles in pure water boiling. Different macro-scale parameters such as shapes, numbers, and contact angle of bubbles also were investigated experimentally and verified by CFD modeling results. Nasr Esfahani [7] performed experiments on nucleate boiling and CHF of Fe3O4/ethylene glycol–water nano-fluid at atmospheric pressure on a horizontal thin Ni–Cr wire. The nano-particles were dispersed in 50 % (by volume) ethylene glycol/de-ionized water as the base liquid in different volumetric concentrations. Experiments showed that boiling heat transfer coefficients deteriorate by increasing nanoparticle concentration in nano-fluid. The addition of nanoparticles delays nucleate boiling incipience and increases CHF.
An experimental study was carried out by Yang and Liu [8] to investigate the pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of functionalized nano-fluid at atmospheric and subatmospheric pressures. Experimental results show that there exist great differences between pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of functionalized and traditional nano-fluid. The differences mainly result from the changes of surface characteristics of the heated surface during the boiling. Therefore, the pool boiling heat transfer of nano-fluids is governed by both the thermo-properties of nano-fluids and the surface characteristics of the heated surface. In another study, Song et al. [9] experimentally investigated on boiling characteristic of SiC nano-fluid and evaluated the thermal performance of SiC nano-particles in water pool boiling up to CHF. The volume concentrations of SiC nano-fluid were 0.0001, 0.001, 0.01 %. The CHF has been enhanced up to 105 % for volume concentration 0.01 %. CHF enhancement trend was interesting because it did not linearly dependent on nanoparticle concentration. The wettability change of SiC nanoparticle deposited surface was discussed as the main reason for CHF enhancement variation.
Boiling behaviors of ZnO nano-fluid on a horizontal and vertical plate in saturated pool boiling was experimentally studied by Mourgous et al. [10]. According to the previous researches, it can be stated that CHF enhancement is the obvious consequence of using nano-fluid under the boiling condition. The main reason for this fact can be referred to the fouling formation of nano-particles on the surface, intensification of capillary wicking and changing in other surface characteristics such as contact angle due to the deposition. Sarafraz et al. [11–15] established experimental studies on the fouling formation and heat transfer characteristics of metal oxide nano-fluids and showed that fouling is a negative parameter, which influence on bubble formation and heat transfer rate. In fact, depending on the surface roughness and type of nano-particles enhancement/deterioration of heat transfer coefficient can be seen for nano-fluids. Shahmoradi et al. [16] performed experimental studies on nucleate pool boiling of alumina based aqueous nanofluid on flat plate heater. They demonstrated that for boiling of nano-fluid (<0.1 vol%) on the heating surface with a ratio of average surface roughness to the average diameter of particles much less than unity when boiling continue to CHF, the heat transfer coefficient of nano-fluid boiling reduces while CHF increases. CHF enhancement increased with the volume fraction of nano-particles.
Ahn and Kim [17] studied the boiling thermal performance of alumina nano-fluid on a wire and examined the saturated water/alumina nano-fluid pool boiling on a plain copper heater under atmospheric pressure. They compared the boiling characteristics of water and alumina. The unusual boiling characteristics (bending point in the boiling curve at a high heat flux), CHF enhancement, and gradual
1 3
increase of wall temperature just after the CHF (instead of the rapid increase of wall temperature) were analyzed based on high-speed visualizations. Kim et al. [18] conducted an experimental study on flow boiling CHF of alumina nano-fluid and alumina coated tubes. The flow boiling CHF of alumina nano-fluid with a plain tube and de-ionized water with an alumina-coated tube were enhanced up to about 80 % for all experimental conditions. There was no big difference in the CHF results between two methods. The obtained results indicate that the CHF enhancement of alumina nano-fluid is surely caused by deposition of nanoparticles on the test section tube inner surface.
Lee et al. [19] conducted experiments on the effects of a magnetite-water nano-fluid (MWNF) on the CHF enhancement using a Ni–Cr wire in pool boiling. All experiments were performed at a saturated condition under atmospheric pressure. The CHF values between the MWNF and the other nano-fluids with several volume concentrations were compared to evaluate the effect of the MWNF on the CHF enhancement. The CHF values of the MWNF were enhanced from approximately 170–240 % of pure water as the nanoparticle concentration increased. In addition, the CHF for the MWNF showed the highest value among the evaluated nano-fluids. In most of the studies, as can be seen in the literature, nano-fluids can enhance the CHF and sometimes increase the heat transfer coefficient, while there are studies in which deterioration of heat transfer coefficient due to the fouling formation of particles have been reported [20–23].
In this work, a set of experiments is performed to quantify the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of Iron oxide aqueous nano-fluids. Influence of different operating parameters such as applied heat flux to the boiling surface and mass concentration of nano-particles on the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of Iron oxide nano-fluids is experimentally investigated and briefly discussed. Bubble formation as the major boiling sub-phenomena and fouling formation as the major challenge of nano-fluids in thermal engineering systems are visually studied and briefly discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1 Experimental setup
sections.text:
Figure 1 presents a schema of the experimental setup used for measuring the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient and CHF of iron oxide nano-fluids. This test rig consists of four main sections:
• Discoid copper heater as the test section with roughness approximately equal to 650 nm.
• Auxiliaries including pre-heater (500 W), coiled pipe condenser (quenched by ethylene glycol/water 50:50 by volume) installed above the test vessel to condense the evaporations. • Temperature measurement instruments including k-type thermocouples, RTDs, indicators, data acquisition (Keithley instruments) and a post processor (a quad processor Intel PC computer). • Imaging system including a high-speed camera (Casio EX-F1 with frame rate 1200 frame per s) and a digital microscope with magnification of 500× (IP-U500x).
Nano-fluid is loaded through the inlet port of the test vessel. The vessel is a vertical Pyrex-made cylinder, which has enough thermal resistance against the high heat flux condition. At the bottom section of the stainless steel cap, a perforated hole is created to install a discoid copper heater. A small layer of Teflon is used to prevent from any liquid leakage and heat loss between the discoid heater and the hole. This discoid heater consists of a dual diameter cylinder with an axial concentric hole at the bottom, in which a 300-W bolt heater is plugged to supply the required heat (See Fig. 2).
The power supply of the heater is provided by an AC regulator (transformer) connected to the urban power supply. More details on geometrical specifications of the discoid heater are given in Fig. 2. The top surface of the discoid heater is fixed horizontally, so the surface can be used for pool boiling heat transfer and CHF experiments. The surface is circular with roughness of 650 nm and outer diameter of 11 mm.
In order to measure the temperature of the surface, five k-type thermocouples with the length of 50 mm and diameter of 1 mm (with the precision of ±0.1 K) are mounted in the axial holes (at different axial positions). By installing the thermocouples, the axial temperature gradient can accurately be measured, which precisely extrapolates the surface temperature of the heater. To ensure about radial heat transfer, two k-type thermocouples at (r = −0.5, r = +0.5) was mounted to measure the radial temperature distribution. Results showed that temperature at this two points are the same at any given heat fluxes, so radial heat transfer can be ignored. To minimize the thermal resistance of each thermocouple, holes are filled with silicon paste. The circumference of the heater is heavily isolated by the cylindrical PTFE, (polytetrafluoroethylene) solid to prevent from any heat losses. By heavily isolating the heater, axial heat transfer towards the surface is guaranteed and no radial heat transfer can be seen in the heater. For measuring the liquid bulk temperature, 4 RTDs (with the precision of ±0.1 K) are installed at four different locations of the test vessel. The arithmetic average of RTD readings is considered as the bulk temperature of the vessel.
1 3
To ensure about saturation boiling, an RTD is mounted at the upper part of the vessel to measure the vapor temperature. A pressure transmitter is also installed to record the pressure inside the vessel. A safety pressure valve is connected to the pressure controller and pressure transmitter to control the pressure of the vessel. An auxiliary heater is installed inside the vessel to supply the required heat for pre-heating of liquid up to saturation temperature. As soon as nano-fluid temperature reaches to the correspondence saturation temperature and pressure, the discoid heater is turned on for starting the pool boiling experiments.

sections.heading: 2.2 Nano‑fluid preparation and quality tests
sections.text:
In order to prepare the nano-fluids, gamma Fe3O4 nanoparticles were purchased from US-Nano with mean particle size of 20 nm. Di-ionized water was selected as the base fluid. The preparation steps summarily include: (1) a desire weight of Iron oxide (at wt% of 0.1–0.3) was initially dispersed into the water/nonylphenol ethoxylate using motorized magnetic stirrer with speed of 250 rpm for 30 min. Noticeably, surfactant can change the thermo-physical properties of nano-fluid, therefore, it was added to DIW at only 0.1 % of general volume of nano-fluid. Then, nanofluid was exposed to sonication process using ultrasonic 40 kHz/300 W for 30 min to prevent from aggregation and
possible clustering formation. In addition, for the best stability, pH of nano-fluids was set using buffer solution of NaOH and HCl (0.1 mM). The pH values of nano-fluids were set to 9.1, 9.6 and 10.1 for wt% of 0.1 to 0.3 respectively. In this condition, nano-fluids were stable for more than 21 days. To ensure the morphology, dispersion and
quality of prepared nano-fluids, TEM images were taken from the nano-fluids.
Figure 3 shows the dispersed nano-particles inside the deionized water. As can be seen, no agglomeration or clustering can be seen and particles are similar to each other in terms of morphology. In addition, the mean particle size was found to have a satisfactory agreement with that of claimed by the manufacturer (20 nm).
To check the purity of nano-particles, X-ray diffraction (XRD) test was implemented. The obtained pattern represented in Fig. 4 demonstrated that there is no significant impurity inside the iron oxide nano-particles and peaks are broad due to the nano-sized effect.
To ensure the stability of the nano-fluid, time-settlement experiments were conducted to minimize the quantity of deposition and scale formation inside the nano-fluid. For enhancing the stability of the nano-fluids, initially, suspensions were stirred at a speed of 210RPM and for various stirring times as given in Table 1. Afterward, nano-fluids were exposed to sonication at a frequency of 40 kHz and throughput of 400 W. Also, in order to enhance the dispersion capability of the base fluid and to prevent from agglomeration, nonylphenol ethoxylate was added to each nano-fluid, followed by measurement of pH. Results showed that the minimum settlement layer was formed when pH, time of sonication and surfactant extent were optimized as represented in Table 1. As the surface charge of the particles has a major role to play, the zeta potential of each nano-fluid was measured using the Malvern instrument and have been reported in Table 1. As can be seen, the obtained results for the zeta potential values are in a good agreement with the result of stability experimentally obtained by settlement-time experiment.
Table 2 represents the properties and nano-particle specifications.

sections.heading: 2.3 Data reduction and uncertainty
sections.text:
For estimating the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, it is essential to extrapolate the surface temperature of the discoid heater. The criterion for thermal performance of
1 3
a nano-fluid is the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, which can be calculated using Eq. (1):
In Eq. (1), Tw is the surface temperature, and Tb is the bulk temperature of the liquid, q is the applied heat flux to the liquid from the discoid heater, which can be calculated using Eq. (2):
Z is the axial direction (see Fig. 2). Noticeably, according to the Joule’s heating effect, heat flux can be directly estimated by Eq. (3) as follows:
In this equation, V is voltage (V), I is an electric current of the central heater (A) and R is the radius of the surface of the discoid heater. Note that, the circumference of the discoid heater has been isolated with PTFE. Therefore, one-dimensional conduction heat transfer is the reasonable dominant heat transfer mechanism. Thus, the following linear temperature distribution can be obtained based on Eq. (2):
Since at z = 0, T = Tw, therefore, we have:
where, α is the intercept of the line fitted on the measured axial temperatures of the discoid heater at a given heat flux. Therefore, alpha can be accurately estimated for each heat flux and is regarded as the surface temperature for each heat flux. A comparison between the heat fluxes estimated from Eq. (2) and that of calculated by Eq. (3) is made to show the quantity of heat loss along with the discoid heater. Figure 5 shows the results of this comparison. Noticeably, thermocouples and multi-meter readings were carried out three times to ensure about the reproducibility of data. It can be stated that at lower heat flux, higher uncertainty was seen (for some data more than 6 %), while for high heat flux condition, lower uncertainty was registered.
As can be seen in Fig. 5a, uncertainty for the applied heat flux is lower than 6 %, meaning that heat can easily flow from cartridge heater towards the boiling surface and rate of heat loss is reasonable and less than 6 %. Figure 5b shows the extrapolation of surface temperature using Eqs. (1–5) for heat flux 400 kW/m2. In addition, a comparison was made between extrapolated surface temperature and data measured by a thermocouple mounted on the surface.

Results were in a good agreement with those of measured by thermocouple within the deviation of 8 %.
For all other heat fluxes, similar extrapolation method was performed to obtain the surface temperature.

The maximum calibration error of the thermocouple was 0.1 K. The maximum deviation related to the measuring of the location of the thermocouples was about 0.1 %. The measurement error of the power meter (multi-meter and current meter) was 0.5 %. Maximum uncertainties of the heat flux and heat loss were also about 9 % and less than 6 % respectively. The uncertainty of heat transfer coefficient according to Eq. (6) equals to 10.1 %. Table 3 represents the uncertainty values of instruments used in the present work.

sections.heading: 3 Results and discussions
sections.text:
Before running the experiments, the integrity of results should be examined. Therefore, experimental data for DIwater are compared to Cornwell–Houston correlation [26] and extrapolated Gorenflo, Rohsenow correlations [27] (for heat transfer coefficient close to CHF) and Zuber [27] (for CHF) at different heat fluxes and represented in Fig. 6. It can be stated that results are in a good agreement with available correlation. This validation shows that experimental data obtained for iron oxide nano-fluids can be highly reliable.
As can be seen in Fig. 6, Cornwell–Houston correlation can predict the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of deionized water with higher accuracy rather than other examined correlations. For other correlations, it can be seen that experimental results have been under-predicted and over-predicted by Rohsenow and Gorenflo correlations respectively. Noticeably, Rohsenow and Gorenflo correlations depend on the thermo-fluid properties and their internal tuning parameters, which should accurately be adjusted. Since properties of DIW are well known and available in handbooks, therefore, these correlations can be considered as the reference. In addition, Zuber correlation predicts the CHF with a reasonable accuracy in comparison with our work (1100 vs. 1170 kW/ m2). After validating the results, nano-fluids were loaded into the system and experiments were established. Results have been represented in following sections.

sections.heading: 3.1 Influence of heat flux
sections.text:
Heat flux has a strong influence on the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient such that with increasing the applied
heat flux, the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient drastically increases. In terms of heat transfer mechanism, it can be stated that at low heat flux region, the dominant mechanism is natural convection (where no bubbles are formed on the surface). At high heat flux region, bubbles are formed

Cornwell-Houston, Rohsenow and Gorenflo are 7.8, 12.4 and 10.9 %, respectively
1 3
and therefore, due to the bubble interactions and bubble transport, the rate of heat transfer significantly increases [28–30]. Overall, with increasing the heat flux, heat transfer coefficient considerably improves, which is due to the bubble sub-phenomena. Figure 7 presents the influence of heat flux on boiling behavior of Iron oxide nano-fluids at wt% = 0.1.

sections.heading: 3.2 Influence of mass concentration
sections.text:
To investigate the influence of mass concentration on the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of nano-fluids, enhancement ratio is defined as:
In Eq. (8), hnf is the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient for nano-fluid, and hbf is the pool boiling heat transfer of base fluid, which is deionized water. Figure 8 demonstrated the influence of mass concentration on heat transfer coefficient. As can be seen, with increasing the mass concentration of nano-fluids, heat transfer coefficient increases such that for wt% = 0.3, enhancement ratio was found to be 29 %. Figure 9 represents the enhancement ratio for Iron oxide nano-fluids.

sections.heading: 3.3 Critical heat flux
sections.text:
As mentioned in the previous section, boiling of nano-fluids may result in CHF delay, which is investigated in this section.
According to the experimental data, CHF or CHF for Iron oxide nano-fluids can be enhanced with increasing the mass concentration of nano-fluids. In fact, by adding
(8)Enhancement ratio = hnf
hbf
more nano-particles, the rate of deposition on the surface considerably increases. Therefore, a capillary action on the boiling surface is created, which holds more liquid inside the fouling layer, since the fouling layer is a porous layer. Therefore, CHF can occur at higher heat fluxes. Noticeably, CHF crisis happens when all the liquid around the surface turns to the vapor and due to the lower thermal conduction of vapor in comparison with liquid, heat cannot be properly transferred to the bulk of fluid. Subsequently, heat transfer coefficient considerably decreases and leads to the surface damage or heater failure [31–34]. Table 4 shows the obtained results for CHF and the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient enhancement. As can be seen, Iron oxide nanofluids are a good option for improving the thermal performance and CHF delay simultaneously.

sections.heading: 3.4 Bubble and fouling formation
sections.text:
A visualization study using high-speed video recorder Exilim Ex-F1 was performed to investigate the influence of applied heat flux on the bubble formation. According to the results, Bubble formation was found to be strongly under the influence of heat flux. With increasing the heat flux, rate bubble detachment considerably increases. Moreover, the size of the bubble increases due to the bubble coalescence phenomenon [35–37]. Besides, due to the bubble agitation and local movements of the bulk of liquid around the bubbles, heat transfer coefficient was found to increase. Briefly
1 3
speaking, at higher heat fluxes, bubble transport phenomena are intensified. Figure 10 shows the influence of heat flux on bubble formation for DI-water. As visualization study of bubble formation in dark nano-fluid is difficult than DIwater, bubble formation at different heat flux for DI-water was visually investigated. Note that the heat transfer rate in pool boiling fully depends on the bubble generation. For different cases, the bubble formation changes and thus the whole heat transfer process changes.
Noticeably, near the surface, bubbles become larger at higher heat fluxes due to the bubble coalescence phenomenon and form the mushroom-shaped bubbles, which is called vapor blanket. This vapor blanket can cover the heating surface and deteriorate the heat transfer rate from the surface. Therefore, the role of bubbles at higher heat fluxes (near the CHF) should carefully be considered, which is out of goals of this work.

sections.heading: 3.5 Fouling formation
sections.text:
The fouling formation is also another phenomenon, which considerably can influence on the pool boiling heat transfer of nano-fluids. In fact, it is generally
believed that deposition of particles as fouling on the surface can create a massive thermal resistance, which deteriorates the heat transfer coefficient and thermal performance of nano-fluids. In order to investigate the role of fouling of iron oxide nano-fluids, a digital microscope IPU500x was utilized and successive images were taken from the boiling surface at the different time of operations.
Figure 11 presents the fouling formation of Iron oxide nano-particles on the surface at different operating times. As can be seen, the fouling formation is considerably intensified with the time such that with increasing the time, fouling formation thickness of surface considerably increases, which results in a higher thermal resistance. The interesting point of this study is related to this fact that during the fouling formation on the surface, the heat transfer coefficient does not change over the time, which means that the iron oxide fouling has no significant impact on the boiling thermal performance of nano-fluid. All the findings in this work are in a good a good agreement with those of obtained in previous publications [27– 42] and this work is regarded as a confirmation for our previous works.
1 3

sections.heading: 3.6 Comparison with the bibliographic data
sections.text: In order to validate the experimental data, a rough comparison was performed between the obtained data and those of available in the literature. Based on the comparison, results showed a satisfactory agreement with the bibliographic data with the maximum deviation of 20.5 %. Results of comparison have been presented in Fig. 12.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text:
Experimental investigations on pool boiling heat transfer to Iron oxide nano-fluids were performed and following conclusions have been made:
• It was found that heat transfer coefficient could be enhanced by adding the solid nano-particles in comparison with the deionized water. • For the conducted experiments, the rate of enhancement could be intensified with increasing the mass
concentration of solid particles ranged from 0.1 to 0.3 % by weight and applied heat fluxes up to CHF point as well. • In terms of bubble formation, results demonstrated that bubble formation is a direct function of heat flux. By increasing the heat flux, the rate of bubble formation and size of bubbles significantly increases. • For fouling formation, as expected, it can be stated that fouling formation is a strong function of time such that with increasing the time, rate of fouling increases.
Acknowledgments Authors of this work dedicate this article to Imam Mahdi and appreciate Semnan University for their scientific supports.

referenceMentions.context: Therefore, to have an efficient cooling system, efforts should be made to increase the CHF point [4].
Such nano-suspensions have higher thermal conductivity in comparison with conventional fluids, so they can be utilized for high heat flux applications and as efficient cooling working mediums [5].
[6] investigated the dynamics of bubbles in pool boiling of nano-fluid with coated and sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) solution with different nano-particles.
Nasr Esfahani [7] performed experiments on nucleate boiling and CHF of Fe3O4/ethylene glycol–water nano-fluid at atmospheric pressure on a horizontal thin Ni–Cr wire.
An experimental study was carried out by Yang and Liu [8] to investigate the pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of functionalized nano-fluid at atmospheric and subatmospheric pressures.
[9] experimentally investigated on boiling characteristic of SiC nano-fluid and evaluated the thermal performance of SiC nano-particles in water pool boiling up to CHF.
[16] performed experimental studies on nucleate pool boiling of alumina based aqueous nanofluid on flat plate heater.

Ahn and Kim [17] studied the boiling thermal performance of alumina nano-fluid on a wire and examined the saturated water/alumina nano-fluid pool boiling on a plain copper heater under atmospheric pressure.
[18] conducted an experimental study on flow boiling CHF of alumina nano-fluid and alumina coated tubes.
[19] conducted experiments on the effects of a magnetite-water nano-fluid (MWNF) on the CHF enhancement using a Ni–Cr wire in pool boiling.

metadata.abstractText: Boiling heat transfer is an efficient and cost-effective mechanism, which has wide application in cooling and power Abstract This paper experimentally focuses on the pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of gamma Fe3O4 aqueous nano-fluids on a flat disc heater. The nano-fluid used in this research was prepared using two-step method and was stabilized using nonylphenol ethoxylate nonionic surfactant, pH setting, and sonication process as well. Influence of different operating parameters such as heat flux (0–1546 kW/m), mass concentration of nano-fluids (weight concentration 0.1– 0.3 %), bubble formation, critical heat flux (1170 kW/m for water, 1230 kW/m (wt% = 0.1), 1320 kW/m (wt% = 0.2), 1450 kW/m (wt% = 0.3) and fouling on pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of nano-fluid as a thermal performance index were experimentally investigated and briefly discussed. Results demonstrated that the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient increases with increasing the mass concentration and the applied heat flux. In addition, the rate of bubble formation is significantly intensified at higher heat fluxes and subsequently, larger bubbles detach the surface due to the intensification of bubble coalescence. In terms of fouling formation, it can be stated that fouling of nano-fluids is a strong function of time and rate of deposition is increased over the extended time while the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient was not decreased over the time, as porous deposited layer on the surface are detached from the surface by bubble interactions. In terms of critical heat flux, capillary action of the deposited layer was found to be the main reason responsible for
